Problems seen in gynecological clinic
The quality. of the services
offered by the Gynecological
Clinic of the Brown Infirmary
has been called into question due
to the decision at the beginning
of this semester to substitute
nurse-midwives for the doctors
previously on call at the Clinic.
Bonnie King, the Nurse
Administrator of the Student
Health Services, indicated that
the decision to change to the
nurse-midwife service was made
this summer. At that time, it was
decided that the needs on the
campus were mostly routine and
could be handled adequately by
nursemidWives, she said.
Numerous undergraduate
women, however, have protested

that the service presently offered
is not adequate, but all those
contacted requested that names
be withheld. "I would think
doctors should be there for
counseling," said one.
"Personally, I would want to go
to a gynecologist if I had a
problem."
"When I go to a gynecological
clinic," commented another, "I
want to see a certified
gynecologist," while one
commented that "a doctor
should be there to prescribe
medication and to handle
problems."
King, however, contended,
"For the population present on
campus and the problems that

arise there is little that a
nurse-midwife can't handle."
"They offer a full scope of
contraceptive counselling for all
devices, including history-taking
to find out which type of device
is most desirable for the
individual student," she asserted.
The training program for
nurse -midwives invdlves a
graduate program, usually of two
years' length, culminating in a
Masters degree in Nursing or
Public Health with a specialty in
midwifery. In order to enter such
a program one must already have
a Bachelors degree and be a
registered nurse.
According to both King and
Kathy Slone. Chief

Nurse-midwife, the Clinic handles
mostly routine examinations and
contraceptive counseling, as well
as common gynecological
problems. As it also covers dependents of students, there are a
few pre-natal patients.
Several more extensive
problems have been referred to
specialists at The Hopkins
Hospital this semester. "The
nurse-midwives can also be
helpful in abortion counseling if
necessary," King asserted.
"A midwife is trained to
handle normal obstetric and
gynecological patients," Slone
explained. "We operate under
standing orders from supervising
physicians.'

Alumni Association to use students for fund-raising

Nelson Cover

By LAINY STEPHANS
The Hopkins Alumni
Association is planning to involve
students in its fund-raising
activities and use the sophomore
class's successful pancake
breakfast as incentive for
increased donations from alumni,
revealed Nelson Cover of the
Alumni Association.
Cover, who will coordinate
student involvement in
fund-raising, stated that the
Hopkins Fund's directors were
impressed with the $400 profit
that the sophomore class made
that will go to the Work-Study
program.
"We broached the idea of how
the Fund can help and decided
the most efficient way would be
to have a mailing supervised by
the Student Support program,"

Cover explained.
This program, directed by
Harry Gotwals, raises funds for
student scholarships by mailing
letters to approximately 300
corporations and individuals.
"We have written these people
once this year and some have
responded with gifts. Now is the
time for a follow-up letter with
the news of the sophomore
class's $400 profit as an example
.of student fund-raising. We hope
this will encourage more people
to make gifts," Gotwals said.
He commented that he had no
idea how successful this
campaign will be. "The people
we will be contacting have not
responded in two years."
The letters will probably go
out in January, Gotwals
explained, and then students may
be asked to speak personally to
those alumni who do not
respond.
"Some people respond better

to personal visits, while others
prefer a letter," Gotwals noted.
Cover said that the Hopkins
Hundreds Campaign hopes to
make increased use of students in
phonathons this year.
He noted that several stud. nts
have already expressed interest in
working on the campaign.
"We send out two mailings
each year asking for gifts, and
then follow up the letters with
phone calls to alumni -who gave
in the past, but have not
responded this year," he
explained.
Alumni who pledge a donation
receive a form on which they can
specify towards which broad
category, such as scholarships,
Arts and Sciences, or the Medical
School, they wish their donation
to go.
Cover was optimistic about the
effect of student fund-raisers,
noting that Stanford University
instituted a similar plan several
years ago which was successful.

the Nixon personality on

New York Times reporters discuss govt. and press
By PATRICE GALLAGHER
Robert Reinhold, reporter for
the Boston office of the New
York Times, and a former editor
of the Hopkins News-Letter, and
Bill Kovach, News Editor for the
Washington Bureau of the New
York Times, spoke at the Sunday
Experience this week on
"Government and the Free Press:
Post Watergate."
Reinhold opened the
discussion with his own
interpretations of the effects of
Watergate on journalism today.
He indicated that although the
role of the press in the Watergate
has been admirable, it has had
one primary detrimental effect:
the florification of what
Reinhold termed "hot-breaking
stories."
Dust
Now that the dust has settled
on Watergate, I think we can
reflect a little bit about it,"
Reinhold commented. "I'm
proud as any reported about
what the press has done...I think

we can take credit for ridding the
country of a poisonous kind of
cancer. But it has had some
negative effects." he stated.
Positive
"There has lieen a positive
trent in journalism in recent
years towards less and less
breaking news-there was more
and more emphasis on
trends...getting more and more
stories that aren't obvious,"
Reinhold continued. He
contended that the Watergate
affair has made the investigative
reporter a "hero," making it
difficult for those reporters
whose stories involve
interpretation of the trends set
by events, as well as investigation
of the events.
"It is clear that the message
young reporters are getting is
that the rewards are for breaking
a scandal, which is faving effect
on serios reporting. The reward
structure of hournalism does not
encourage good reporting."
Kovach then spoke, agreeing

with Reinhold's comments, and
adding a few interpretation of his
own. "Watergate really dislocated
a number of trends that were
important at the New York
Times as well as other
newspapers across the country."
he asserted.
One of these trends Kovack
spoke of was the decreasing
importance of the "source
story", stories obtained from
unidentified sources.
According to Kovack, "people
love gossip," and this has been
the primary reason for the
popularity of stories about
Watergate and related scandals in
government.
"The Rockefeller nomination
is being covered the same way
Watergate was covered."
Because of the dominance of
the Nixon personality on
Washington in recent years,
Kovach contended that this has
caused the press to "ignore the
underlying ussues."
"Washington has become

dominated by personality
coverage rather than an issue
orientation, and this has caused a
problem for the reading public
and the industry."
Floor
After Kovach spoke, they
opened the floor to questions
xhich centered on a concern for
more press coverage of the
financial structure of the nation,
the role of the press secretary (in
reference to the recent
resignation of press secretary
Jerry terHorst), and the role of
the press in the Watergate
scandal.
